titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Civic Engagement and Government Program, Office Files of Amy Brown
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Civic Engagement and Government Program, Office Files of Amy Brown FA1846

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 18:28:02 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Civic Engagement and Government Program, Office Files of Amy Brown

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.
This material was transferred to the RAC in 2021 in two different sets of records and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2021:016 and Accession 2021:120.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series 1. General files, 2007-2015 Series 2. Grant files, 2008-2016

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the files Amy Brown created when she worked as a Program Officer at the Ford Foundation, focusing on programming for financial justice and for providing financial opportunities and protections to low and moderate-income and marginalized communities. Most of the records in the collection originate from Brown's position as a Program Officer in the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Financial Assets Unit. There are also some documents created by Brown when she was a Senior Program Officer in the Civic Engagement and Government Program which was her last position at the Foundation.

The collection is comprised of two series with the bulk of the collection's contents contained in the second series. The first series contains general files mostly concerning convenings and program strategy, and the second series contains grant files documenting grant approvals, related communications and support, and reporting. Grantees focused on issues regarding affordable financial services and products, debt, credit unions, predatory lending, financial savings, financial reform and regulation advocacy, and the impact of new technology on the financial marketplace among other topics.

In addition to the grant status reports (GSR), grant communication summaries, and Recommended Grant Actions records (RGA) in the grant files, there are also materials like correspondence, reports, meeting materials, notes, drafts, and articles found throughout the collection.

did.unittitle: General files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files in the series primarily concern convenings and program strategy and evaluation for Amy Brown's work related to the Ford Foundation's programing for financial justice and providing financial opportunities and protections for low and moderate-income and marginalized communities. They were mostly created during Brown's position as a Program Officer in the Foundation's Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Financial Assets Unit.

Program strategy and evaluation records in the series include grantee surveys, initiative results, reports, and a Learning Memo. Other common material formats found in this series include correspondence, notes, and drafts.

scopecontent.p: D2D (Doorways to Dreams) Fund is now called Commonwealth.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation Grantee Convening - Financial Justice and the National Conversation on Race
Ford Foundation Grantee Convening - The Intersection of Worker Justice and Financial Justice
Grant files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains grant files Amy Brown created when she worked as a Program Officer in the Ford Foundation's Economic Opportunity and Assets Program, Financial Assets Unit and then closed or continued to manage as Senior Program Officer in the Foundation's Civic Engagement and Government Program. Files document the approval, support, and reporting of individuals grants. Reflecting Brown's program aims of financial justice and expanding financial opportunities and protections to low and moderate-income and marginalized communities, grants in the series focus on:

- Promoting access to affordable and fair financial products and services - Addressing issues regarding debt including student debt for higher education, credit card debt, public utility debt, unfair credit reporting practices, and racial and class disparities around debt - Expanding access to credit unions - Protecting consumers from predatory lending - Protecting homeownership and access to housing - Encouraging financial savings and matched savings programs and promoting savings approaches like tax times savings - Research into how families manage their financial lives for its implications on policy and financial products design - Financial reform and regulation advocacy - Increasing staff and leadership diversity in Federal financial regulatory agencies - Addressing technology changes in the financial marketplace such as big data and its impact on consumers as well as utilizing new technological approaches like mobile banking
Communities which grants in the series center include Latino, Black, and immigrant populations.

Brown's grant files typically contain grant status reports (GSR), grantee communication summaries, and Recommended Grant Action records (RGA). A GSR includes the grant's grant number which is incorporated into the title of every grant file in the series when that information is provided. Grantee communication summaries describe discussions, phone calls, meetings, and site visits related to specific grants and have records of those communications and notes attached to them. An RGA includes the grant's request number which is incorporated into a scope note on each grant file in the series.

Later records from 2015 to 2016 document the strategic shifts happening at the Ford Foundation during that time which changed Brown's role to Senior Program Officer in the Civic Engagement and Government Program. Some grants Brown had managed were transferred to her colleagues Leah Mayor and Anna Wadia during the transition while others she continued to monitor.
Files in this series also contain other kinds of reports, correspondence, meeting materials, drafts, and articles.
